measured_by: Punishment-learning-rate parameter from the Reward–Punishment computational model (prl_rp_multipleB) fitted to the Probabilistic Reversal Learning task
justification: The Methods note that the Reward–Punishment Model for Multiple-Block Probabilistic Reversal Learning "estimates three parameters: (1) punishment learning rate, (2) reward learning rate, and (3) inverse temperature," specifying this model parameter as the measure of punishment learning rate.

measured_by: Reward-learning-rate parameter from the Reward–Punishment computational model (prl_rp_multipleB) fitted to the Probabilistic Reversal Learning task
justification: In describing the same computational model, the authors list "reward learning rate" as one of the three parameters the model estimates, indicating this parameter is the operational measure of the construct.

measured_by: Inverse-temperature parameter from the Reward–Punishment computational model (prl_rp_multipleB) fitted to the Probabilistic Reversal Learning task
justification: The paper states that the model also outputs an "inverse temperature parameter," which reflects the degree to which learned values are translated into exploratory vs. exploitative choices.

measured_by: Alpha (α) scaling exponent derived via detrended fluctuation analysis of heart-rate-variability time series
justification: Under Autonomic Psychophysiology the authors explain that an "alpha (α) score for each participant was generated...providing a summary index of levels of psychophysiological engagement via how organized or presumably 'fractal' their system was."

measured_by: Total points sum score (correct hits − false alarms) on the adapted probabilistic reversal learning task
justification: The Measures section states that "A summation of points across the three response types...was used to index overall performance, where higher scores indicate more 'optimal' performance."
